<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">A Co(II) coordination polymer, Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpa<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-diphenic acid, 2,2′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine), was prepared by a hydrothermal method and characterized in detail. The dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand offered two carboxylate groups to construct two monodentate configurations that connected two Co(II) centers to form a 1D chain. Multiple 1D chains stacked on each other to generate a 3D framework via the weak C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>π</ce:italic> interaction. Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> exhibited an efficient catalytic performance for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The highest turn-over frequency (TOF) of 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> was obtained at the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to cyclohexene of 1:16000.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A Co(II) coordination polymer, Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 (H2dpa=2,2'-diphenic acid, 2,2'-bipy=2,2'-bipyridine), was prepared by a hydrothermal method and characterized in detail. The dpa2- ligand offered two carboxylate groups to construct two monodentate configurations that connected two Co(II) centers to form a 1D chain. Multiple 1D chains stacked on each other to generate a 3D framework via the weak CH⋯ π interaction. Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 exhibited an efficient catalytic performance for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The highest turn-over frequency (TOF) of 979h-1 was obtained at the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 to cyclohexene of 1:16000.

</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0030">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The coordination polymers (CPs) possessing the properties of both coordination compound and macromolecule have been designed, constructed and applied in various fields, such as sensing, magnetism, luminescence and catalysis . They are especially considered as an excellent catalyst due to their single active sites and easy separation only found in homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts, respectively . 2,2′-diphenic acid, a well known O-donor ligand, can assemble CPs with various architectures because of its adjustable coordination ability derived from the distortion of its two benzene rings connected by C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C bond . Compared with the construction methods using a single ligand, combining the carboxyl-containing and N-heterocycle-containing ligands to construct CPs has gradually become an effective and facile synthesis strategy to achieve desirable structures and properties . Some metal ions, such as Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, In<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, along with the combination of 2,2′-diphenic acid ligand and 2,2′-bipyridine ligand, have been used to construct many novel CPs with macrocycles or helical chains microstructure by hydrothermal reactions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
A novel Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was synthesized and characterized.

Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 catalyzed allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by O2.

The efficient catalytic performance with a TOF up to 979h-1 

Introduction

The coordination polymers (CPs) possessing the properties of both coordination compound and macromolecule have been designed, constructed and applied in various fields, such as sensing, magnetism, luminescence and catalysis . They are especially considered as an excellent catalyst due to their single active sites and easy separation only found in homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts, respectively . 2,2'-diphenic acid, a well known O-donor ligand, can assemble CPs with various architectures because of its adjustable coordination ability derived from the distortion of its two benzene rings connected by CC bond . Compared with the construction methods using a single ligand, combining the carboxyl-containing and N-heterocycle-containing ligands to construct CPs has gradually become an effective and facile synthesis strategy to achieve desirable structures and properties . Some metal ions, such as Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, In3+ and Zn2+, along with the combination of 2,2'-diphenic acid ligand and 2,2'-bipyridine ligand, have been used to construct many novel CPs with macrocycles or helical chains microstructure by hydrothermal reactions .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The allylic oxidation of cyclohexene produces two important chemical intermediates, 2-cyclohexene-1-ol (Cy-ol) and 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one). However, the conventional oxidation procedures involve metallic compounds, chemical oxidative reagents and organic solvents, which can cause severe environmental pollutions. Therefore, green catalytic oxidation processes, especially solvent-free oxidation by oxygen, have been attracted considerable attentions. Various catalysts have been developed to achieve this goal. It was reported that the gold nanoparticles over modified silica with diameters of 5–10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm exhibited a high catalytic activity for solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexene at 353<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K under 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar oxygen . Metal organic framework (MOF), an important branch of 3-dimensional (3D) CPs, has been widely used as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst in cyclohexene oxidation due to its highly porous structure and facile accessibility of substrate molecules to its active sites. For example, a chiral Co(II) metal-organic framework containing a thiazolidine-based spacer ([Co(<ce:inf loc="post">L</ce:inf>-RR)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>) was exploited for the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene, in which a conversion of 36.7% was achieved at 343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K under low-pressure oxygen, with Cy-one as the main product . The partial substitution of Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> by Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> in Ni-MOF-74 that was inactive enabled a high catalytic activity for solvent-free cyclohexene oxidation . However, the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene usually requires a high turn-over number (TON) or frequency (TOF), which is still a challenge to elevate the catalytic efficiency.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The allylic oxidation of cyclohexene produces two important chemical intermediates, 2-cyclohexene-1-ol (Cy-ol) and 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one). However, the conventional oxidation procedures involve metallic compounds, chemical oxidative reagents and organic solvents, which can cause severe environmental pollutions. Therefore, green catalytic oxidation processes, especially solvent-free oxidation by oxygen, have been attracted considerable attentions. Various catalysts have been developed to achieve this goal. It was reported that the gold nanoparticles over modified silica with diameters of 5-10nm exhibited a high catalytic activity for solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexene at 353K under 13bar oxygen . Metal organic framework (MOF), an important branch of 3-dimensional (3D) CPs, has been widely used as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst in cyclohexene oxidation due to its highly porous structure and facile accessibility of substrate molecules to its active sites. For example, a chiral Co(II) metal-organic framework containing a thiazolidine-based spacer ([Co(L-RR)(H2O)⋅H2O]∞) was exploited for the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene, in which a conversion of 36.7% was achieved at 343K under low-pressure oxygen, with Cy-one as the main product . The partial substitution of Ni2+ by Co2+ in Ni-MOF-74 that was inactive enabled a high catalytic activity for solvent-free cyclohexene oxidation . However, the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene usually requires a high turn-over number (TON) or frequency (TOF), which is still a challenge to elevate the catalytic efficiency.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Extensive studies have been conducted on the development and utilization of 3D CPs, such as MOFs. The catalytic properties and application of 1D CPs have been rarely reported . In the previous work, 2D Co(II) CP constructed by 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid and 2,2′-bipyridine rigid ligands showed poor catalytic efficiency (16.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) due to the low exposure of active sites . It is considered that 1D CPs possess flexible chain structures, which may expose most of the metal active sites to contact with reactant molecules, and thus promote the catalytic efficiency. Therefore, in the present work, a novel 1D Co (II) coordination polymer, Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, was constructed by the hydrothermal assembly of Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> with 2,2′-diphenic acid flexible ligand and 2,2′-bipyridine rigid ligand and fully characterized. Its application as an efficient catalyst for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was demonstrated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Extensive studies have been conducted on the development and utilization of 3D CPs, such as MOFs. The catalytic properties and application of 1D CPs have been rarely reported . In the previous work, 2D Co(II) CP constructed by 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid and 2,2'-bipyridine rigid ligands showed poor catalytic efficiency (16.6h-1) due to the low exposure of active sites . It is considered that 1D CPs possess flexible chain structures, which may expose most of the metal active sites to contact with reactant molecules, and thus promote the catalytic efficiency. Therefore, in the present work, a novel 1D Co (II) coordination polymer, Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2, was constructed by the hydrothermal assembly of Co2+ with 2,2'-diphenic acid flexible ligand and 2,2'-bipyridine rigid ligand and fully characterized. Its application as an efficient catalyst for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by O2 was demonstrated.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0035">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In a typical synthesis procedure of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, 0.0735<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (≥<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>99%), 0.1337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g 2,2′-diphenic acid (96%), 0.0429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g 2,2′-bipyridine (99%) and 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL redistilled water were mixed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave reactor. The pH of reactant mixture was adjusted to 8.2 with NaOH aqueous solution. The reactor was then sealed, heated at 433<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and slowly cooled for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days to room temperature. The product was washed with de-ionized water and filtrated to afford wine rod crystals of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in an average yield of 26.7%. The Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystal was grinded into a powder, washed with ethanol and air-dried to afford a Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> powder (Co-CP) that was used as the catalyst for cyclohexene oxidation. Anal. Calc. for Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: Co, 11.99; C, 58.67; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: Co, 12.05; C, 57.87; H, 4.04; N, 5.53. The characterization of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and catalytic tests were described in the supplementary material. The crystallographic data has been deposited as CCDC 993754.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

In a typical synthesis procedure of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2, 0.0735g Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (≥99%), 0.1337g 2,2'-diphenic acid (96%), 0.0429g 2,2'-bipyridine (99%) and 15mL redistilled water were mixed in a 25mL Teflon-lined autoclave reactor. The pH of reactant mixture was adjusted to 8.2 with NaOH aqueous solution. The reactor was then sealed, heated at 433K for 120h and slowly cooled for 2days to room temperature. The product was washed with de-ionized water and filtrated to afford wine rod crystals of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 in an average yield of 26.7%. The Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 crystal was grinded into a powder, washed with ethanol and air-dried to afford a Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 powder (Co-CP) that was used as the catalyst for cyclohexene oxidation. Anal. Calc. for Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2: Co, 11.99; C, 58.67; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: Co, 12.05; C, 57.87; H, 4.04; N, 5.53. The characterization of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 and catalytic tests were described in the supplementary material. The crystallographic data has been deposited as CCDC 993754.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0040">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The crystallographic data revealed that Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was crystallized in the orthorhombic space group of P2(1)2(1)2(1). The Co1 center exhibited a slightly distorted octahedron geometry that was coordinated with two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6) from two deprotonated dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N8, N11) from one 2,2′-bipyridine and two oxygen atoms (O3, O7) from two coordinated water molecules (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The lengths of Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds are in the ranges of 2.0677(14)–2.1601(14) Å and 2.1215(16)–2.1386(18) Å, respectively, comparable to the lengths of regular Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds . The C, O and O atoms of the carboxylate group and the coordinated Co atom are almost in the same plane with the dihedral angles <<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1°. Compared with their corresponding phenyl rings, the two carboxylate groups in the same dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> molecule are distorted with the dihedral angles of 35.696° and 35.992°, respectively. The two phenyl rings in the same dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> molecule are distorted dramatically with a dihedral angle of 81.769°, approximately perpendicular, consistent to the reported value of 81.9° . The dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> bridging ligand offers two carboxylate groups to construct two monodentate configurations that connect two neighboring Co(II) centers with the Co<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>Co distance of 6.5737(6) Å, resulting in the formation of a 1D chain along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (b). The stability of the coordination structure and chain structure was strengthened by the O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>O hydrogen-bonds between the coordinated water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms of dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands. Multiple 1D chains can stack on each other to generate a 3D framework through the weak C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>π</ce:italic> interaction between the hydrogen atoms (C7-H7) of the pyridyl rings in 2,2′-bipyridine of one chain and the <ce:italic>π</ce:italic> orbitals of the pyridyl rings in 2,2′-bipyridine of another adjacent chain (Fig. S2). The distance of the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>centroid is 2.770<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the gamma angle is 12.38°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The crystallographic data revealed that Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was crystallized in the orthorhombic space group of P2(1)2(1)2(1). The Co1 center exhibited a slightly distorted octahedron geometry that was coordinated with two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6) from two deprotonated dpa2- ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N8, N11) from one 2,2'-bipyridine and two oxygen atoms (O3, O7) from two coordinated water molecules (a). The lengths of CoO and CoN bonds are in the ranges of 2.0677(14)-2.1601(14) Å and 2.1215(16)-2.1386(18) Å, respectively, comparable to the lengths of regular CoO and CoN bonds . The C, O and O atoms of the carboxylate group and the coordinated Co atom are almost in the same plane with the dihedral angles <1°. Compared with their corresponding phenyl rings, the two carboxylate groups in the same dpa2- molecule are distorted with the dihedral angles of 35.696° and 35.992°, respectively. The two phenyl rings in the same dpa2- molecule are distorted dramatically with a dihedral angle of 81.769°, approximately perpendicular, consistent to the reported value of 81.9° . The dpa2- bridging ligand offers two carboxylate groups to construct two monodentate configurations that connect two neighboring Co(II) centers with the Co⋯Co distance of 6.5737(6) Å, resulting in the formation of a 1D chain along a axis (b). The stability of the coordination structure and chain structure was strengthened by the OH⋯O hydrogen-bonds between the coordinated water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms of dpa2- ligands. Multiple 1D chains can stack on each other to generate a 3D framework through the weak CH⋯ π interaction between the hydrogen atoms (C7-H7) of the pyridyl rings in 2,2'-bipyridine of one chain and the π orbitals of the pyridyl rings in 2,2'-bipyridine of another adjacent chain (Fig. S2). The distance of the CH⋯centroid is 2.770Å and the gamma angle is 12.38°.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The phase purity of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was examined by comparing its as-synthesized and simulated XRD patterns (Fig. S3a). The diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized sample are in good agreement with those of the simulated structure, indicating that Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was obtained as a pure crystalline phase. The peak intensity difference between the as-synthesized and simulated XRD patterns is caused by the preferred orientation of powder sample in XRD imaging. After one cyclohexene oxidation run, the XRD peaks of recycled Co-CP particles were located at different position and became broader, and the intensity dropped significantly (Fig. S3b). This indicated that the crystalline structure of Co-CP was completely destroyed during the reactions and the recycled Co-CP particles were approximately amorphous mixture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The phase purity of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was examined by comparing its as-synthesized and simulated XRD patterns (Fig. S3a). The diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized sample are in good agreement with those of the simulated structure, indicating that Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was obtained as a pure crystalline phase. The peak intensity difference between the as-synthesized and simulated XRD patterns is caused by the preferred orientation of powder sample in XRD imaging. After one cyclohexene oxidation run, the XRD peaks of recycled Co-CP particles were located at different position and became broader, and the intensity dropped significantly (Fig. S3b). This indicated that the crystalline structure of Co-CP was completely destroyed during the reactions and the recycled Co-CP particles were approximately amorphous mixture.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">FT-IR analysis was carried out to verify the change of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> structure in the reaction process. Compared with the IR spectrum of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpa (Fig. S4), the invisible vibration band of –COOH functional group centered at ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1680<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> indicates that H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpa lost all protons to form dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>) . The peak at 3558<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> was due to the O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H stretching vibration of coordinated water . The strong adsorption peaks at 1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 1383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> were ascribed to the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups with the wavenumbers difference of 217<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. The difference is greater than that of the free dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion, suggesting that the carboxylate groups in dpa<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand adopted monodentate bonding mode . The strong adsorption peak at around 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> was originated from the out-of-plane bending <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>ibration of Ar<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bond. However, the peaks corresponding to v(O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H) and v(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) stretching vibration disappeared in the spectra of recycled Co-CP particles after reacting for different time, which indicated Co-CP catalyst was completely dehydrated and destroyed during the reactions (b–d). This is consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The IR peaks intensity of recycled Co-CP particles at 1258–1017<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> increased gradually with the extended reaction time, which might be assigned to the stretching vibration of C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond. A new peak at the very low wavenumber of 501<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> appeared in the spectra of recycled Co-CP particles, which became more and more intensive with the extended reaction time. This might be assigned to the stretching vibration of Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond, suggesting the formation of cobalt oxides in the recycled Co-CP particles, which was also proved by the results of Raman analysis in accordance with the literature  (Fig. S5).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: FT-IR analysis was carried out to verify the change of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 structure in the reaction process. Compared with the IR spectrum of H2dpa (Fig. S4), the invisible vibration band of -COOH functional group centered at ~1680cm-1 indicates that H2dpa lost all protons to form dpa2- (a) . The peak at 3558cm-1 was due to the OH stretching vibration of coordinated water . The strong adsorption peaks at 1600cm-1 and 1383cm-1 were ascribed to the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups with the wavenumbers difference of 217cm-1. The difference is greater than that of the free dpa2- anion, suggesting that the carboxylate groups in dpa2- ligand adopted monodentate bonding mode . The strong adsorption peak at around 800cm-1 was originated from the out-of-plane bending vibration of ArH bond. However, the peaks corresponding to v(OH) and v(COO-) stretching vibration disappeared in the spectra of recycled Co-CP particles after reacting for different time, which indicated Co-CP catalyst was completely dehydrated and destroyed during the reactions (b-d). This is consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The IR peaks intensity of recycled Co-CP particles at 1258-1017cm-1 increased gradually with the extended reaction time, which might be assigned to the stretching vibration of CO bond. A new peak at the very low wavenumber of 501cm-1 appeared in the spectra of recycled Co-CP particles, which became more and more intensive with the extended reaction time. This might be assigned to the stretching vibration of CoO bond, suggesting the formation of cobalt oxides in the recycled Co-CP particles, which was also proved by the results of Raman analysis in accordance with the literature  (Fig. S5).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">TGA analysis was conducted to determine the thermal stability of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (Fig. S6). A weight loss of 6.57% occurred in the temperature range from 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C due to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd. 7.33%). The anhydrous complex remained stable up to 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It was collapsed and its organic ligands were completely decomposed between 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 420<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, leading to a high weight loss of 70.34%. The residues weighted 23.09<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was presumed to be the cobalt dicarbonyl compound Co(CO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (calcd. 23.39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt%). A further weight loss of 9.15% was observed above 510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and the residue weighted 14.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> might be attributed to the metal oxide, such as Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (calcd. 16.87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: TGA analysis was conducted to determine the thermal stability of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 (Fig. S6). A weight loss of 6.57% occurred in the temperature range from 130°C to 190°C due to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd. 7.33%). The anhydrous complex remained stable up to 250°C. It was collapsed and its organic ligands were completely decomposed between 250°C and 420°C, leading to a high weight loss of 70.34%. The residues weighted 23.09wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was presumed to be the cobalt dicarbonyl compound Co(CO)2 (calcd. 23.39wt%). A further weight loss of 9.15% was observed above 510°C, and the residue weighted 14.05wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 might be attributed to the metal oxide, such as Co2O3 (calcd. 16.87wt%).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The morphology of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was imaged with a SEM (Fig. S7). Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystal exhibited a rod-like shape with a smooth surface, clear ridge lines, high crystallinity, long length and large diameter, possibly resulting from the self-assembly of the supramolecular 1D chain. And the pulverized Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> exhibited irregular particles consisting of small spherical particles and large rod-like particles.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The morphology of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was imaged with a SEM (Fig. S7). Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 crystal exhibited a rod-like shape with a smooth surface, clear ridge lines, high crystallinity, long length and large diameter, possibly resulting from the self-assembly of the supramolecular 1D chain. And the pulverized Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 exhibited irregular particles consisting of small spherical particles and large rod-like particles.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The TEM images of the ultrasonic dispersed Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> particles revealed the agglomeration of some spherical particles with sizes of 300–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The high magnification image indicates that the spheres were accumulated by many nanoparticles with sizes <<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (b). The disordered accumulation of the nanoparticles also produced an irregular mesoporous structure that, for its high-resolution TEM image (Fig. S8), exhibited clear lattice fringes. The morphology of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> found by SEM and TEM imaging can be explained by its microstructure. The crystallographic analysis indicates that the 1D molecular chains of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were bundled to form nanofibers via the weak C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>π</ce:italic> interaction. The nanofibers could be separated from the crystal rods by pulverization, curled and agglomerated to form nanoparticles due to the surface tension, forming pores in the middle.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TEM images of the ultrasonic dispersed Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 particles revealed the agglomeration of some spherical particles with sizes of 300-700nm (a). The high magnification image indicates that the spheres were accumulated by many nanoparticles with sizes <10nm (b). The disordered accumulation of the nanoparticles also produced an irregular mesoporous structure that, for its high-resolution TEM image (Fig. S8), exhibited clear lattice fringes. The morphology of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 found by SEM and TEM imaging can be explained by its microstructure. The crystallographic analysis indicates that the 1D molecular chains of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 were bundled to form nanofibers via the weak CH⋯ π interaction. The nanofibers could be separated from the crystal rods by pulverization, curled and agglomerated to form nanoparticles due to the surface tension, forming pores in the middle.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The catalytic performance of Co-CP was tested for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The oxidation mainly produced Cy-ol, Cy-one, intermediate 2-cyclohexene-1-hydroperoxide (Cy-HP) and cyclohexene oxide (Cy-oxide) (Fig. S9). The conversion of cyclohexene in the absence of Co-CP was 1.4% (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor> entry 1). The cyclohexene conversion increased from 7.5% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> as the reaction temperature increased from 331<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K to 343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K ( entries 2–4). The selectivity towards Cy-HP decreased from 61.0% to 30.5%, whereas those towards Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide increased to different values, indicating the rapid transformation of Cy-HP to Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide at high reaction temperatures. The cyclohexene conversions increased from 2.1% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> as the reaction time prolonged from 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h to 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h ( entries 4–6). The selectivity towards Cy-HP reached the maximum of 64.3% at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and sharply decreased to 40.7% at 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, while the conversion increased from 7.8% at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h to 36.7% at 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h evidently. Cy-HP was the major product at the initial reaction stage. It was dissociated into cyclohexenyl peroxyl radical (Cy-OO·) via the homolysis of O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H that acted as the main chain propagator. As the reaction proceeded, the free radicals (Cy-OO·) was gradually accumulated, which instantaneously promoted the chain transfer, the dissociation of Cy-HP and the formations of Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The catalytic performance of Co-CP was tested for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The oxidation mainly produced Cy-ol, Cy-one, intermediate 2-cyclohexene-1-hydroperoxide (Cy-HP) and cyclohexene oxide (Cy-oxide) (Fig. S9). The conversion of cyclohexene in the absence of Co-CP was 1.4% (  entry 1). The cyclohexene conversion increased from 7.5% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 200h-1 to 979h-1 as the reaction temperature increased from 331K to 343K ( entries 2-4). The selectivity towards Cy-HP decreased from 61.0% to 30.5%, whereas those towards Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide increased to different values, indicating the rapid transformation of Cy-HP to Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide at high reaction temperatures. The cyclohexene conversions increased from 2.1% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 56h-1 to 979h-1 as the reaction time prolonged from 2h to 6h ( entries 4-6). The selectivity towards Cy-HP reached the maximum of 64.3% at 4h and sharply decreased to 40.7% at 6h, while the conversion increased from 7.8% at 4h to 36.7% at 6h evidently. Cy-HP was the major product at the initial reaction stage. It was dissociated into cyclohexenyl peroxyl radical (Cy-OO⋅) via the homolysis of OH that acted as the main chain propagator. As the reaction proceeded, the free radicals (Cy-OO⋅) was gradually accumulated, which instantaneously promoted the chain transfer, the dissociation of Cy-HP and the formations of Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">With the increase of the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to cyclohexene from 1:16000 to 1:6000, the conversions increased evidently from 36.7%, peaked at 49.6%, and then slightly decreased to 47.2%, however, the TOF decreased from 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to 472<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> ( entries 4, 7–9). These results can be explained that more catalyst provides a large surface area to absorb reactants, resulting in a higher conversion. As the amount of catalyst increased to a certain value, the Co-CP particles began to agglomerate, which led to the slight increase of the surface area. Therefore, the reactant adsorption on the surface of Co-CP particles reached equilibrium and the conversion reached the maximum. The catalytic reaction was then inhibited by higher catalyst doses, once in our previous work, which was reported by Black as “catalyst-inhibitor conversion phenomenon” . Although the conversion of the cyclohexene oxidation increased with the amount of Co-CP particles, the serious agglomeration led to a sharp decrease in the dispersion of Co active sites, leading to a decreased TOF calculated basing on the mole of total Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> ions. The highest TOF of 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> was obtained at the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to cyclohexene of 1:16000 with a total selectivity of 88.5% to Cy-ol, Cy-one, Cy-HP and Cy-oxide.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With the increase of the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 to cyclohexene from 1:16000 to 1:6000, the conversions increased evidently from 36.7%, peaked at 49.6%, and then slightly decreased to 47.2%, however, the TOF decreased from 979h-1 to 472h-1 ( entries 4, 7-9). These results can be explained that more catalyst provides a large surface area to absorb reactants, resulting in a higher conversion. As the amount of catalyst increased to a certain value, the Co-CP particles began to agglomerate, which led to the slight increase of the surface area. Therefore, the reactant adsorption on the surface of Co-CP particles reached equilibrium and the conversion reached the maximum. The catalytic reaction was then inhibited by higher catalyst doses, once in our previous work, which was reported by Black as "catalyst-inhibitor conversion phenomenon" . Although the conversion of the cyclohexene oxidation increased with the amount of Co-CP particles, the serious agglomeration led to a sharp decrease in the dispersion of Co active sites, leading to a decreased TOF calculated basing on the mole of total Co2+ ions. The highest TOF of 979h-1 was obtained at the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 to cyclohexene of 1:16000 with a total selectivity of 88.5% to Cy-ol, Cy-one, Cy-HP and Cy-oxide.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">As shown in the results of the catalyst filtration experiment (Fig. S10), when the Co-CP particles were filtered off from the reaction mixture after reacting for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the conversion of cyclohexene increased from 2.1% to 3.6% in 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and to 8.2% in 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h respectively, which was much lower than the activity in the presence of catalyst. The remained activity in the filtrate can be initiated by the minor oxidation products through free radical autoxidation of cyclohexene, similar as cyclohexane oxidation . So it was suggested that the present reactions actually occurred over the Co-CP particles surface heterogeneously. However, the conversion sharply decreased from 36.7% (the first run;  entry 4) to 5.9% (the second run;  entry 10) in the catalyst recycling tests, which indicated that Co-CP could not be reused due to the damage of its structure during reactions. As discussed in the TGA analysis, Co-CP exhibited a low thermal stability and began to decompose at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, suggesting the low coordination bond energy. At the initial stage of reaction, the free radical induction might cause the breaking of coordination bonds, which resulted in the exposure of Co(II) coordinatively unsaturated sites . The Co(II) coordinatively unsaturated sites could activate the substrate or oxygen molecules to accelerate the reaction rate, which also form strong interactions to aggravate the structure damage of Co-CP. Therefore, the aforementioned speculation should be included in a further mechanism study. Finally, Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> catalyst shows comparable reaction conversion and higher TOF value compared with Co(II) MOFs reported for the solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexene in the similar reaction conditions ( entries 11 and 12).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in the results of the catalyst filtration experiment (Fig. S10), when the Co-CP particles were filtered off from the reaction mixture after reacting for 2h, the conversion of cyclohexene increased from 2.1% to 3.6% in 2h and to 8.2% in 4h respectively, which was much lower than the activity in the presence of catalyst. The remained activity in the filtrate can be initiated by the minor oxidation products through free radical autoxidation of cyclohexene, similar as cyclohexane oxidation . So it was suggested that the present reactions actually occurred over the Co-CP particles surface heterogeneously. However, the conversion sharply decreased from 36.7% (the first run;  entry 4) to 5.9% (the second run;  entry 10) in the catalyst recycling tests, which indicated that Co-CP could not be reused due to the damage of its structure during reactions. As discussed in the TGA analysis, Co-CP exhibited a low thermal stability and began to decompose at 130°C, suggesting the low coordination bond energy. At the initial stage of reaction, the free radical induction might cause the breaking of coordination bonds, which resulted in the exposure of Co(II) coordinatively unsaturated sites . The Co(II) coordinatively unsaturated sites could activate the substrate or oxygen molecules to accelerate the reaction rate, which also form strong interactions to aggravate the structure damage of Co-CP. Therefore, the aforementioned speculation should be included in a further mechanism study. Finally, Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 catalyst shows comparable reaction conversion and higher TOF value compared with Co(II) MOFs reported for the solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexene in the similar reaction conditions ( entries 11 and 12).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0045">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In summary, a novel Co(II) coordination polymer Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was synthesized via the hydrothermal assembly of Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> with 2,2′-diphenic acid and 2,2′-bipyridine. The flexible 2,2′-diphenic acid ligand played an important role in constructing 1D chains and the rigid 2,2′-bipyridine ligand provided a weak C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>π</ce:italic> interaction to form a 3D framework. The Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystal exhibited a rod-like shape with a high crystallinity and low thermal stability. The pulverized Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> powder was used as a novel catalyst for the solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. It showed an efficient catalytic performance for the cyclohexene oxidation with a TOF up to 979<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which might be attributed to the exposure of the Co (II) coordinatively unsaturated sites during the reactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel Co(II) coordination polymer Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was synthesized via the hydrothermal assembly of Co2+ with 2,2'-diphenic acid and 2,2'-bipyridine. The flexible 2,2'-diphenic acid ligand played an important role in constructing 1D chains and the rigid 2,2'-bipyridine ligand provided a weak CH⋯ π interaction to form a 3D framework. The Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 crystal exhibited a rod-like shape with a high crystallinity and low thermal stability. The pulverized Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 powder was used as a novel catalyst for the solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. It showed an efficient catalytic performance for the cyclohexene oxidation with a TOF up to 979h-1, which might be attributed to the exposure of the Co (II) coordinatively unsaturated sites during the reactions.

The pH of reactant mixture was adjusted to 8.2 with NaOH aqueous solution. The reactor was then sealed, heated at 433<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and slowly cooled for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days to room temperature. The product was washed with de-ionized water and filtrated to afford wine rod crystals of Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in an average yield of 26.7%. The Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystal was grinded into a powder, washed with ethanol and air-dried to afford a Co(dpa)(2,2′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> powder (Co-CP) that was used as the catalyst for cyclohexene oxidation. cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

In a typical synthesis procedure of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2, 0.0735g Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (≥99%), 0.1337g 2,2'-diphenic acid (96%), 0.0429g 2,2'-bipyridine (99%) and 15mL redistilled water were mixed in a 25mL Teflon-lined autoclave reactor. The pH of reactant mixture was adjusted to 8.2 with NaOH aqueous solution. The reactor was then sealed, heated at 433K for 120h and slowly cooled for 2days to room temperature. The product was washed with de-ionized water and filtrated to afford wine rod crystals of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 in an average yield of 26.7%. The Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 crystal was grinded into a powder, washed with ethanol and air-dried to afford a Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 powder (Co-CP) that was used as the catalyst for cyclohexene oxidation. Anal. Calc. for Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2: Co, 11.99; C, 58.67; H, 4.10; N, 5.70. Found: Co, 12.05; C, 57.87; H, 4.04; N, 5.53. The characterization of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 and catalytic tests were described in the supplementary material. The crystallographic data has been deposited as CCDC 993754.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A Co(II) coordination polymer, Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 (H2dpa=2,2'-diphenic acid, 2,2'-bipy=2,2'-bipyridine), was prepared by a hydrothermal method and characterized in detail. The dpa2- ligand offered two carboxylate groups to construct two monodentate configurations that connected two Co(II) centers to form a 1D chain. Multiple 1D chains stacked on each other to generate a 3D framework via the weak CH⋯ π interaction. Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 exhibited an efficient catalytic performance for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The highest turn-over frequency (TOF) of 979h-1 was obtained at the molar ratio of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 to cyclohexene of 1:16000.

Highlights

   ⋅ A novel Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was synthesized and characterized.   ⋅ Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 catalyzed allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by O2.   ⋅ The efficient catalytic performance with a TOF up to 979h-1    

TGA analysis was conducted to determine the thermal stability of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 (Fig. S6). A weight loss of 6.57% occurred in the temperature range from 130°C to 190°C due to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd. 7.33%). The anhydrous complex remained stable up to 250°C. It was collapsed and its organic ligands were completely decomposed between 250°C and 420°C, leading to a high weight loss of 70.34%. The residues weighted 23.09wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was presumed to be the cobalt dicarbonyl compound Co(CO)2 (calcd. 23.39wt%). A further weight loss of 9.15% was observed above 510°C, and the residue weighted 14.05wt% of Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 might be attributed to the metal oxide, such as Co2O3 (calcd. 16.87wt%).

The catalytic performance of Co-CP was tested for solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. The oxidation mainly produced Cy-ol, Cy-one, intermediate 2-cyclohexene-1-hydroperoxide (Cy-HP) and cyclohexene oxide (Cy-oxide) (Fig. S9). The conversion of cyclohexene in the absence of Co-CP was 1.4% (  entry 1). The cyclohexene conversion increased from 7.5% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 200h-1 to 979h-1 as the reaction temperature increased from 331K to 343K ( entries 2-4). The selectivity towards Cy-HP decreased from 61.0% to 30.5%, whereas those towards Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide increased to different values, indicating the rapid transformation of Cy-HP to Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide at high reaction temperatures. The cyclohexene conversions increased from 2.1% to 36.7%, and TOF increased from 56h-1 to 979h-1 as the reaction time prolonged from 2h to 6h ( entries 4-6). The selectivity towards Cy-HP reached the maximum of 64.3% at 4h and sharply decreased to 40.7% at 6h, while the conversion increased from 7.8% at 4h to 36.7% at 6h evidently. Cy-HP was the major product at the initial reaction stage. It was dissociated into cyclohexenyl peroxyl radical (Cy-OO⋅) via the homolysis of OH that acted as the main chain propagator. As the reaction proceeded, the free radicals (Cy-OO⋅) was gradually accumulated, which instantaneously promoted the chain transfer, the dissociation of Cy-HP and the formations of Cy-ol, Cy-one and Cy-oxide.

Conclusions

In summary, a novel Co(II) coordination polymer Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 was synthesized via the hydrothermal assembly of Co2+ with 2,2'-diphenic acid and 2,2'-bipyridine. The flexible 2,2'-diphenic acid ligand played an important role in constructing 1D chains and the rigid 2,2'-bipyridine ligand provided a weak CH⋯ π interaction to form a 3D framework. The Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 crystal exhibited a rod-like shape with a high crystallinity and low thermal stability. The pulverized Co(dpa)(2,2'-bipy)(H2O)2 powder was used as a novel catalyst for the solvent-free allylic oxidation of cyclohexene by oxygen. It showed an efficient catalytic performance for the cyclohexene oxidation with a TOF up to 979h-1, which might be attributed to the exposure of the Co (II) coordinatively unsaturated sites during the reactions.
